description: From Middle English knelen, knewlen, from Old English cnēowlian (“to kneel”), equivalent to knee +‎ -le. Cognate with Dutch knielen (“to kneel”), Low German knelen (“to kneel”), dialectal German knielen, kneulen, knülen (“to kneel”), Danish knæle (“to kneel”).

verbs.description: kneel (third-person singular simple present kneels, present participle kneeling, simple past and past participle knelt or kneeled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To rest on one's bent knees, sometimes only one; to move to such a position.
(intransitive, of a bus or other vehicle) To sink down so that the entrance is level with the pavement, making it easier for passengers to enter.

examples: She knelt the doll to fit it into the box.
He knelt him down to pray.
